Overall, our tourist guest was disappointed and I am going to remove Prado from our lineup.  There are many other comparable choices in the area that I prefer.  Among others, T Cook's and Lon's at the Hermosa offer the same fancy resort feel, and have better food in my opinion, now that Prado's menu has changed.

Made reservations through Opentable on 12/22 for reservations at 8:15 pm at Prado on 12/31/12 for a New Years and my birthday celebration.  Called Prado the next day to confirm just to be sure.  On the day of the reservation, hostess called me and left a msg to see if we were doing New Years Eve menu or not.  Upon calling back, we were notified that there were no 8:15 spots like we had booked and there was only seating at 6 or 9 and only a New years eve menu was to be offered at either $90 (at 6pm) or $150 (at 9 pm) per person.  This was quite inconvenient especially since I am a vegetarian and was counting on being able to order from the regular dinner menu.  Manager had no suitable solutions to offer us and we cancelled.  Extremely disappointed in opentable and Prado.  WIll not dine here in the future and will unrecommend to others.
Good service. Nice atmosphere. Rubbery burger. 6 raviolis for 18 bux.

visited Prado for my 22nd birthday dinner. Sad to say that this place is just OK. We started off with the burrata appetizer served with foccacia bread (which was untoasted). flavor was good but hard to enjoyed with cold, chewy bread. I had the sea scallops with chorizo risotto. Dish came with 3 beautifully cooked and seasoned scallops and mediocre risotto. The mister got the gnocchi dish which was excellent, however portion size was SO small. Enjoyed two cocktails one with some ginger syrup, great. I do not recommend the purple haze drink. Overall, the menu selection was small and the cuisine did not meet the standards of fine dining. Total ripoff and I would not return.

Grandpa and Carmen are the best.  I think people mistakenly review the restaurant with the hotel etc.  This is the place for Sunday brunch! The views are truly amazing!  We eat at only the finest restaurants and I'm telling you this is a great place!  Relax and enjoy!

The food was good. Not outstanding, but not junk either. I had the Squid Ink Angel Hair Pasta ($29) and my wife had the Rib Eye ($42). Pretty pricey for what you get, but we are staying at Montelucia Resort for our honeymoon and aren't counting pennies this week. The restaurant is beautiful and comfortable and the employees were really nice. I think we'll try something off property for our next dinner.
Great atmosphere.... food was decent but expensive, of course being a hotel restaurant. Service was the pits. Just thought I would share.

Prado restaurant supports the Spanish village theme of Montelucia Resort with a wide-open communal atmosphere that houses both the restaurant and the lounge. A cozy space is carved out for the lounge where live music is often being performed. There is also a patio that takes advantage of the stupendous views of Camelback Mountain.   The meal I had at Prado was spectacular. Each item my guest and I tried was uncomplicated, yet with an air of sophistication. Each dish was clean and healthful, allowing the natural flavors of the food to shine through.

I wish I can give zero star for their poor, unacceptable service. Neither the waiter nor the manager knew the cocktail my friend ordered, which had been on their menu but discontinued at some point; instead of offering alternatives, the manager told the waiter to "make something similar to blah blah" in a very snappy manner. We could very well hear you - only two feet away from you. Strangely excellent quality service coming from a bar in a renowned Omni Resort!

Probably my worst dining experience ever. Waited over 10 minutes after being seated for waiter to come over. We decided on breakfast buffet -- BIG mistake.  Boring items -- undercooked eggs, cold pan cakes, bacon, sausage, fruit, oatmeal, yogurt parfait and omelets to order.  No bowls were out for the oatmeal -- had to ask 2 different people to get me one. Then discovered were out of oatmeal and were making more. Then no yogurt parfait -- asked to have some more made to the waiter.  Waited over 15 minutes and still nothing.  Waiter then just came to our table and without saying a word, placed the bill for $58 on our table.  Never came to fill our empty water and juice glasses and never apologized for them being out of the oatmeal and parfait. As we were leaving, overheard couple in front saying they too would never return.

Omni Hotel & Resorts 4949 E. Lincoln Drive Scottsdale, AZ  In keeping with my tradition of visiting restaurants during Arizona Restaurant Week, we visited Prado. Prado is a Spanish themed restaurant located in the hotel.  Companion and I arrived at 6:30 and were promptly seated. The hotel has valet parking, however your ticket will be stamped by the restaurant which will give you free parking.   Restaurant week features a prix fixe menu which in this case was $44 per person. I started out with a roasted beet salad set with frisee greens, balsamic vinegar and some blue cheese. The beets were nicely tender and were beautifully sweet. Companion had a mini loaf of bread filled with Brie cheese and served with a lemon curd. The mixture of flavors was wonderful. We also ordered their crispy Calamari which was absolutely fabulous.  For main courses, we both ordered the Paella. Companions was cooked nicely, and mine was mush. Instead of properly cooked socarrat which is the crispy rice that should be on the bottom of a good paella, I had mushy rice and peas. The maitre d came over to our table and asked how the dinner was. I told him honestly that it was fair. He offered to take the dish back and change it for something else, which I appreciated but declined to do. However, it should be noted that he did let the chef know about this problem. Without the socarrat, paella just isn't paella regardless of how good the flavor might be.  For dessert, companion ordered the Crema Cata, which is very similar to a creme brulee. Companion pronounced it very good. For myself, I ordered the Berry Crumble, which was loaded with berries and was quite tasty with a ball of vanilla ice cream on the top.  Dings - The dining room was on the noisy side due to the bar being in the same area with a T.V. set blaring and showing a game in which many were cheering. It would be nice if there were some way to separate the bar from the dining room.  There is a guitar player in the front of the dining room trying his best to be entertaining. Unfortunately, the bass notes carry throughout the dining room but the melody is totally lost.  The restaurant is clean, and service is excellent.  4 stars for cleanliness, service, and outstanding appetizers.
Great food and atmosphere. Particularly enjoyed the Veal over Polenta. Divine. Staff was really friendly

I love Prado.  I have dined there several times and every time the food options are better and better. The Halibut is out of this world.  The service can be slow at sometimes but the atmosphere and live music makes up for it.  Prado practices the slo food movement and I think that is why the servers take their time.  The Mbar in the front of the venue has happy hours that are a lot of fun $5 wine and tapas which allow you to sample the menu at an affordable price.  Definitely going back!

The Omni Montelucia resort is beautiful! The resort's main restaurant Prado is great for casual bar food or elegant special occasions. My friend and I came on Saturday night and sat outside when the weather was perfect! The atmosphere was so elegant and cozy, service was very accommodating and the food was delicious! This is a great place to escape into the Spanish Moroccan style scenery and imagine being in another country....Prado is definitely one of my favorite Valley spots.

$23+ tax seemed a bit pricey for a breakfast buffet, but always being in the adventurous spirit, we went to Prado to try out the buffet before indulging in a spa treatment at Joya.  All the ingredients here are fresh and well prepared.  The hot buffet today consisted of pancakes, breakfast quesadilla, applewood bacon, pork sausage, and roasted potatoes.  The bacon was excellent- perfectly crispy, not at all chewy, with great subtle smokey flavor, not too salty at all.  The potatoes were also excellently cooked,  as well as the sausage.  The quesadilla was decent, but tasted a bit too cheesy for me.  They have an omelet and Belgian waffle station as well, made to order.  The omelet I had was excellent- very fluffy with fresh ingredients.  The cold selections are also diverse and flavorful as well.  There is a wide selection of fresh fruit, pastries, cheese and bread, smoked salmon, and divine fruit and granola parfaits.  I'm sure these parfaits aren't really that healthy for you since they taste so good, but they are probably some of the best breakfast items I've had in a long time!  The yogurt in the parfait is whipped to a light airy consistency, and sprinkled with spiced granola, crisp nuts, candied fruit, and fresh fruit.  The buffet includes juice, coffee, tea, and milk.  Service was a bit sluggish initially, but picked up later on.  There is a wide selection of juices to choose from, and the coffee is very smooth.    Generally, this isn't a buffet I'll be going to a whole lot, but if I'm in the mood for splurging and indulging in a buffet for breakfast, I'll know where to go.

Nice ambiance. Long wait for server to take our order for drinks. Had to grab the waiter's attention and he acted like he forgot about us and made it seem like we were the ones taking a long time deciding. No. We ordered. Then the wait. Ordered and appetizer (calamari) which came quickly enough and tasted good. Then the real wait for the entrees. 45 minutes or so. Food tasted pretty good but small portions. No follow up from the waiter. We were done with our food and finally he came by but to deliver food to the table next to us. No acknowledgement at all. Seriously? We got up and left. We're staying at the resort so we figure they'll bill the room anyway. Awful service. Much like the rest of these reviews.

BAR ONLY--wandered down here one night from the Camelback Inn just to check the place out (it's only about a 15-minute walk, with a dramatic view of CB mountain all the way). We stopped in at the bar and had a few drinks; the whole place has a very pre-fab feel like some set designer's version of an Italian estate, which seemed jarring after the authenticity of the Camelback. The drink menu is extensive, though they were out of a few things. It's a little spendy, but not too awful. Seems like they may do quite a bit of group business at the hotel, because there was a group of drunk, loud douchebag conventioneers at one end of the bar.  I will say the bar staff was wonderful--very friendly and attentive, but after a couple of drinks I felt like I'd gotten all I ever would out of this place.

So this was good. Fine. And damn expensive. I mean, I like good food and I'm willing to pay for it. To the tune of about $2.50/bite of brie, I GUESS I really like to pay for it.   The paella was pretty good, but it didn't have the rustic, crusted-to-the-pot delight that paella at other restaurants (for me) had in the past. It was really a nice copper-ish pot with buttered rice and veggies and a dollop of chimichurri sauce on top. It was good, but expensive and not REALLY paella IMO.  We had excellent service and it was romantic and perfect outside with the dim lights, but I might have still left hungry having spent over $100 for dinner (minus the drinks). Hmph.

To me, this is a typical resort restaurant.  They are working very hard to make sure their restaurant is as upscale as possible & by concentrating on that, they miss the mark in other important areas (food, comfortable atmopshere...).  I have a few pet peeves--when they insist on putting your napkin on your lap.  When they trick you into buying bottled water.  Things like that.  I also don't like when they tell you a fish is very similar to sea bass and it's just tilapia in disguise.  Not a fan.    I stayed at this resort and LOVED it.  But I think they went in the wrong direction with their restaurant.  They really should take a lesson from BLT Steak down the street on what a more successful restaurant is doing and what the customers want.

You are definitely paying for the resort's view when you come here. The outdoor patio is alongside a beautiful fountain row, surrounded by palm trees, with a breathtaking view of the Camelback mountains. The high arches of the patio give it a palatial feel.   We opted for the continental breakfast ($26/person) since most of the main items that were featured on the breakfast menu (~15/dish) were included, along with coffee and orange juice. There is an omelette bar, waffles, breakfast tacos, potatoes, lox, yogurt parfait, and fruit. The food was mediocre at best-- I had very little motivation to finish any of the cooked dishes. The quality was what I would expect at a Denny's or hospital cafeteria (albeit a higher end hospital). The yogurt parfait was unfortunately the best item; the waffles weren't bad.   Especially since I was staying at the resort so had already basqued in the view and there are so many great places to eat in Scottsdale, I should've been less lazy and left for lunch.

I visited Prado for my father in-laws birthday. Our host had our reservation for 10 in the private dining area ready. To start, I had the rebel cocktail, which had fresh raspberries and pomegranate syrup, it was refreshing. Next we had four boards of assorted meats, cheeses, jelly and nuts as an appetizer. The manchego cheese was really good, especially paired with the apricot jelly. The boards also came with lamb chops which were seasoned tender and cooked just right.   For my entree I had the lobster, scallops and pasta special. The lobster was a bit chewy and was not easy to cut. The scallops however, were cooked perfectly.   My only complaint would be our service. Because we were in the private dining area, it seemed we were forgotten. Our water was not being refilled and it was taking to long for us to request more drinks, food etc.  Overall a pleasant visit, I will most likely visit again.

The customer service here is unbelievable. The employees seem genuinely happy to work there and they treat the guests like family. I was very impressed with this resort in general. But i particularly love this restaurant and the food there.   Our first night there we ordered all of the salads and they were the best salads I've ever had. Cauliflower, beets... and everything was very fresh.     On our final night we ordered a lot of the seafood. Again delicious and fresh. I'm taking a star off because the kitchen should be prepared for demand and we didn't get to have what I will call the most Incredible and accurate crème brûlée I have ever had stateside. The best!    Also the elderly man who does brunch service. I want to say he was called "grandpa frank?" What a delightful man. It's a fantastic brunch with a plenty of fresh fruit and cheeses. Lots of egg dishes and a ton of pastries/sweets (including the crème brûlée)     I will be definitely come back time and time again.

Ate breakfast here during my stay and was thoroughly disappointed. While my over easy eggs had a runny yoke, they had been tragically cooked too quickly. They were tough and difficult to cut. My bacon was hard, dry and overdone. The service was good, but I'm not sure if that would entice me to return.

hubs and I stayed at Montelucia to celebrate our 4th year anniversary. Starving after checking in the resort so we headed straight to Prado.  we were greeted warmly and was seated right away. the hostess was really nice, she checked on us a few times during the meal and was very helpful in recommending food. Our server was also great. she even insisted to give us a anniversary dessert even though we were too full.  we're glad we took that dessert though because that banana foster was to die for!  We had crab cake and white kale salad for starters.  both were fabulous. had pasta while hubby had the steak... very good. drinks were good as well and servers were really helpful.  we also came back for Sunday brunch and had the same server. brunch was a bit busy and the omelette chef was a bit slow but it didn't bother us.  would love to be back.

From the best sour dough bread & pesto before the meal to an awesome margarita & the most tender calamari I've ever eaten to the Sea Bass that melted in my mouth & had an incredible sauce with capers & potatoes.  Prado was so good!  Highly recommend!!

Came for brunch and made the mistake of sitting at a high top by the bar since there was a wait for seating in the main dining room. We had the brunch buffet so the food was easy to access but no one ever came to wait on us so had to ask the hostess for utensils and a random waiter for drinks who never followed up with us again (I assume they thought we were being helped by someone else). We had to get the hostess to track down another random waiter to get our check printed too.  I like buffets in that there is minimal interaction with wait staff but SOME I think is needed. You know, so you can have a water while you're choking down your dry pancake. I think it was $20 for the buffet and $26 for bigger buffet option where you could get sausage links, bacon and pancakes. That isn't clearly labeled though so just look at the menu at what the continental $20 buffet entails if you don't want the bigger one. The continental comes with a waffle an omelet station where you could build your own. That cook did make me a pretty great omelet. Also, the restaurant setting itself was nice- and glad I tried it since I hadn't before but I wouldn't go back.

Amazing place!  The food is spectacular - the atmosphere wonderful.  The food is "clean" not mucked up.  The staff is great.  Poolside lunch is great too!  And they dont sweat you for being a "local" to enjoy the pool/resort!  This is my favorite resort in Scottsdale, hands down!  Mainly because I don't feel like I am in Scottsdale!  Love this place!

Upon arriving we were greeted by a gentlemen in a pink sport coat. He proudly introduced himself as Grandpa Frank and asked us to choose our seating. Breakfast and our service was great. Thank you Cindy for the hospitality.

I give this place two starts because it is very pretty. The restaurant is picture perfect and why shouldn't it be? It is after all in the Montelucia Resort. The food on the other hand was pretty bad. It was bad compared to other hotels and to other restaurants. I was here for breakfast so I am not sure what dinner or lunch is like. I ordered the mushroom and cheese omelet that came with potatoes. My bf ordered the spinach frittata that came with fruit. Neither of our dishes were tasty. Both of us couldn't finish it. This is the key piece of information here. I always finish my plate. Breakfast is my favorite meal of the day and I was very sad at my situation. There just was no taste to it. Completely bland and not worth $15.

I can't help but laugh at the name Prado, being in Paradise Valley, I always think of old wealthy ladies with their PradA bags eating here.   Anyway, the restaurant is the least attractive part of the resort, and still blows a lot of places away in terms of beauty. If you get a chance to tour the property, you'll see what I mean. The spa, rooms, and other public areas are unbelievable. I looked for a place where they skimped and could not find one... then I walked into Prado, and lo and behold, it may be that skimp.  I dined on pallea, a few tapas plates, and had a couple of samplings from their extensive wine list. The Chorizo sausage is amazing, but where they lost me was with the seafood. Maybe they are concerned with food-bourne allergies a little too much because I've never had mussels that were soooo rubbery.   The bar area is gorgeous as well, and has plenty of seating in the lounge as well as at the bar. I might reccommend someone to come in and check out the bar, have a small plate, and peace out. Try other, more well established restaurants in the area, but don't pass up the Montelucia without seeing it. The place really is jaw-dropping.

Went back to the Montelucia on Saturday night with another couple. Drinks and appetizers at Mbar and then dinner at Prado. I absolutely love this place. All four meals were mouth watering good and the service was amazing. Truly a favorite. Head over before sunset. The grounds are spectacular!

Classy. Food is usually a fusion of sorts depending on the Chef the have working for them at the time. This changes super frequently. But the food is always top notch. Ambience is very elegant and a place to take a date to impress.

Great atmosphere and beautiful food presentation. Brunch was solid but not excellent.  The wait staff was attentive but not overbearing.  Recommendation to management: either shut the outside doors or ensure birds don't come inside. Seems to be an issue for the Phoenix and Scottdale areas in general.

Painful. The food was pretty good, but for the price, I would've expected better food and at least a semblance of meaningful service. Truth-be-told, the entire Omni Montelucia resort seems to be in a fog of lousy service and about a 25-minute time delay.  The only reason why you'd eat here is because you're too drunk leave the property and too intoxicated to care about: 1) time, 2) money, 3) indifference from staff. The only bright spot was the busser from somewhere in Eastern Europe who couldn't speak much English but she was delighted to fill our waters -- maybe no one else showed up to work that day.  (Which is entirely plausible since it appeared that our server was also the bartender and clearly had too much on his hands to deal with us.)  As I write this, I realize that this lousy experience can only be chalked-up to one thing: mismanagement.  Don't reward mismanagement, go someplace else.
Came here with my boyfriend this weekend for my birthday and loved it! Service was great, decor is spot on and the food was fantastic. I recommend the mushroom risotto - it's fantastic!
Great ambiance and even better staff and drinks. Probably one of the most hidden hotspots around town. I'm telling you, just try it one time. You'll be back...I promise!

Review is for Breakfast brunch/buffet:    We actually finally got to try Prado after we checked out, for the breakfast buffet.  It consisted of an omelet station,  french toast, mini breakfast burritos, sausage, fruit, toast, cereal and milk and pastries.    I had the egg white omelet with ham, cheese, spinach a slice of french toast, fruit, coffee and orange juice and it was all very good, above average.   The price is $25 per person which included food, orange juice, coffee at the buffet,  I believe that is comparable to other resort buffets, or Las Vegas prices.  The last thing I wanted to mention is that if you want to have alcoholic drinks you can go for the $45 buffet which includes food and all you can drink Mimosa's or bloody Marys.

Went there together with four other people for brunch.  We got the outdoor seating we had requested on the covered patio.  Initially the service wasn't great as we weren't contacted right away by a waiter, but later became very good.  I decided to do the "full breakfast buffet" but they also have a "continental breakfast buffet" and a la carte.   The restaurant is very nice with a rustic touch. The outdoor patio has a long fountain close by and there is a fabulous view of Camelback Mountain.  I must say that re breakfast buffet was a little disappointing as I had expected many more different choices, more like a Las Vegas-style buffet.  It is certainly sufficient but I think that a 5-star resort should do better for the price of $26.00.   Alex, our service was very attentive with a big smile on his face.

I went to Prado during Restaurant Week with my favorite dining companion Mike B.  It was my "Last Supper" before getting my tonsils out this week.  Since it's Friday night and I just had Jello for dinner, I thought this is a good time to reminisce about Prado and write my very 1st Yelp review.     We had early reservations for Sunday night.  Service was great, waiter was handsome (sure, I say it matters), decor was very comfortable and nice.  Since it was during restaurant week, our selections were from a limited menu, but the $29 included a glass of wine.  Bonus!   I have to assume that the Restaurant week menu has smaller servings than the regular menu, because for one of our appetizers, the Day Boat Scallops, was actually one scallop.  It was good, but I added salt to it, which I rarely do.  For dinner I really enjoyed the flat iron steak, very tender, great flavor.   For dessert we tried a Hazelnut cake and a chocolate cake with gelato.  I thought the Hazelnut cake was the big winner - light and delicious.  I think it's hard to really judge a restaurant during restaurant week, just because it's difficult to tell how things like portions translate to the regular menu (like the one scallop).  Now if only I had been smart and scheduled my tonsils to come out AFTER restaurant week, I'd have more restaurants to review.  ;)

Not impressed at all- poor service, poor attention to drinks, orders etc. our server rarely made it by to check on us regarding food drinks and water- order was messed up and it took til the end of my meal to fix it! For what you pay at such a nice upscale resort , service was far below par!

Such a gem in a beautiful desert landscape. Hidden behind the walls of the Montelucia resort in Paradise Valley, you may never know about this place until someone told you about it. Service is impeccable and you have a kitchen full of chefs to create anything your heart could ever want. It's a great place to have a date, sitting and overlooking the pool on the patio, or having brunch and mimosas with the girls -- or guys.   Seriously. You have to try it.

Tried out their short rib on restaurant week menu, definitely one of the best ever, tender meat with perfect flavor. Salad and cooked broccolini also delicious with just the right amount of dressing that mixed well.  Cheesecake as dessert however was a bit lacking but not bad.

Came here on a Tuesday night w my husband for the first time. Not my first time at Montelucia but was my first time having dinner at Prado. The ambience and interior was very romantic and quaint. Perfect for date night. Our server Amal was super attentive and knowledgeable of the menu n wine selection pairings.   We started off w the rioja wine. Amazing recommendation from our server Amal. And the bacon wrapped dates was fantastic. It was grilled to perfection.  As my entree, I got the short rib and my husband got the scallops. Both so delicious!! It was heaven in my mouth.   I definitely recommend this place. The food service and ambiance was perfection. Super romantic!!

As we were at the Montelucia resort for the night we figured we would check out their 'Slow Movement' restaurant Prado. Well slow service just what we received. The place was busy (not jammed) and the waiters just couldn't cope, The service was painfully slow and our guy was frankly jaded. He said all the right things but you didn't believe a word of it.  I had some delicious scallops but with polenta that was essentially fancy grits. I have tasted much better elsewhere. I went on to lamb for my entree which was OK, but again just OK.   To top off the evening our red wine was served at room temperature and I mean Arizona with no AC room temperature! Not good.   I would pass on this place and if you are staying at the otherwise excellent resort. Jump in a cab and head to the nearby excellent Tarbells on Camelback Road.

So we asked the waiter about dinner, he recommended  we go to El charros,  should say it all. Service was what you would expect from a diner or a fast food restaurant,  but this was not one if those. We decided to stay here instead of the Phoenician. What a mistake. So far!!!! The whole hotel leaves a lot to be desired.  Not close to the 4.6 stars it's rated as a hotel but restaurant is not in  the league  of a 4 star, but to say it is a 5 star hotel resort ha ha!!!  (2 star works).    Food was very 2nd class.   Service was less.  Had dinner reservations for a birthday  day celebration  tonight here but we're going to El Charros  instead! !!

Breakfast here was great! I didn't eat in the restaurant for dinner, but I did order food to eat in my room! Breakfast: I had the huevos rancheros on one day and the brioche French toast on another day. The huevos was excellent and had good presentation! The French toast was good, but I wasn't blown away by it. The portion size was huge though, which was good and the fruit was very fresh! I had an iced coffee that was good, although I wish they had served the milk separate because it was a little too milky for me. Service: The service for breakfast was good and quite quick, although on July 4th the restaurant was quite busy and it took a while to get our food.  Atmosphere: I would recommend getting an indoor seat because during the summer it is way too hot to sit outside, and I was there in the morning!  Dinner: My parents ordered a burrata appetizer which was so delicious, although the amount of cheese was disappointingly small. They also got the braised beef with potato gnocchi, which was so so so good! The portion size is definitely quite large, with two big hunks of meat. I got a kids pasta, which was pretty standard.  Price: I would say that the food is a bit on the pricier side, but it's not too bad when you take the portion size into consideration! Overall it was a pretty good experience, especially for a hotel restaurant!

Our family had 9am reservation for Father's Day and it was a perfect time since there were very few people in the restaurant. It was quiet and the service was great. We all decided to get the breakfast buffet which was $26.00/person. It came with 2 cooked to order items. Omelets with a nice selection of fillings and a huge, fabulous waffle that was light flaky with just the right amount of crunch. Several baked items to choose from like cinnamon buns that were delicious, sticky, crumbly topping with a little bit of bacon on top.  There was actually more food than we could eat; bacon,  sausage, french toast, potatoes, scrambled eggs and sausage besides from fruit, yogurt.  Our waiter was very prompt with refills on water and coffee and removing dirty plates. It is a lovely restaurant in a  perfect setting, right at the foot of Camelback mountain.

We visited Prado for their NYE event while visiting Scottsdale. They had a deal for a four-course prefix menu (vegetarian options available), champagne (one bottle per couple), and dancing/party favors for $125 per person (plus gratuity and taxes). Out of all the NYE events in the area, this one seemed best in terms of price and festivities.  The restaurant is beautifully set behind the grand fountain at the Omni Hotel. The indoor space is large and it seemed trendy but not too crowded early in the evening.   Dinner: For the first course we got a Moroccan lentil soup, which was tasty and rich. We then moved onto to an arugula and date salad, which was small but delicious. For the main course, there were 2 options. The gnocchi was amazing- smooth and silky, and the pasta was melt-in-you-mouth good! The quinoa lasagna on the other hand was quite lackluster. It had too much of a raw feel without enough flavor. For dessert we got the key lime pie and chocolate cake. Both were great, but the key lime pie won by a narrow margin.   The champagne bottle was top-shelf (Verve) and a live band played the night away. We toasted the new year with party favors and a sea of balloons falling from the ceiling in the center of the dance floor. The dancing area was definitely crowded and we felt there wasn't enough space for the number of people there.  All-in-all a pricey dinner (over $150 per person), above average food, but a great experience! If we were to do it again, it would have been better to have dinner elsewhere and then visited Prado for drinks, dancing, and NYE favors later in the night.

Went to The Prado at the Omni Resort at Montelucia for the first time on a Saturday evening in the course of entertaining out-of-town guests.  Superb job on the overall design of the restaurant, and the staff is very friendly and attentive.     Appetizers (warm manchego and caramelized cauliflower) were excellent, as were the entrees (lamb chops, salmon, center cut filet and lemon chicken).  Service was exceptional, and an accomplished guitarist provided background music (Ottmar Liebert-style selections).  This is an easy place to recommend.

Stayed at the Omni for our 2nd honeymoon trip in Arizona. Went to Prado for a late dinner, the menu was mostly just appetizers and small plates. Had the Spanish marguerite pizza. Which was amazing! Husband had the lamb chops and loved it, it was a small portion so he wished he would of got something else or 20 of those(haha!). Breakfast buffet was good, had all the necessary items: bacon sausage mini breakfast burritos fruit and the best omelet station ever! We got served by Carmen both mornings and we absolute LOVED her! Hands down the best server we've had in a while! Don't forget to try their pineapple mimosa

Stayed at the Omni for the weekend and the Prado was our breakfast spot. Grandpa Frank is the sweetest man on earth. He took great care of us and his hospitality was one of a kind. Kind, welcoming and hilarious. Wouldn't have been the same without him. The Omni is lucky to have him!
